HUM•DAH

The Home Mortgage Disclosure Act

Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) ·

Modernizing government data into useful tools for both experts and the curious.

Read the full case study (8 mins)

Each year, thousands of banks and other financial institutions report data about mortgages to the public as part of the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act, or “Hum-Dah," for short. HMDA data is a view of the mortgage market, an important part of the American economy. But with over 18.7 million records reported by 7,400 financial institutions in 2012 alone, working with the data can be overwhelming. As a user experience designer (and occasional code contributor), I helped deliver a tool that gave users accurate data.

Context

This project was a joint effort between two areas of the Bureau. A team of mortgage lending industry experts needed to publish a large amount of data as mandated by the Dodd-Frank Act. Members of the Technology and Innovation team were building a new platform to increase public access to open data. The project was an opportunity to increase government transparency, a major goal of the Bureau.

1.

With two product owners representing different industries, participatory design exercises were essential for collaboration during the discovery phase of the project. In many ways, this phase of the project resembled a crash course in statistics for designers. But without it, the team would be unable to deliver a usable, accurate product, and any empathy on our part would be mere sympathy.

The first needfinding session would reveal that traditional personas would be insufficient for this project. The potential audiences we identified as a team were too many; their roles, workflows, and quirks, too disparate.

Different audience prioritizations favored one product owner over another. For a product with a highly-techical existing audience, it was important to make stakeholders feel that audience heard.

The win depended on detaching UX success away from a deliverable and focusing instead on how to guide a conversation. I took a step back in my process and found that I was mapping potential audiences across two themes: technical expertise and subject matter expertise. I reframed needfinding artifacts into user story hooks, definitions of success, and biggest risks. Bringing a visual representation of different types of people and their work to the table (no pun inteded) facilitated relative, not ad-hoc, prioritization.

At this point, I didn't even have to deliver a pitch anymore. As a designer, I didn't see the potential audiences as technical or not; subject matter experts or not. Rather, I saw people who wanted to hear stories and those wanted to tell them; people who had questions and those that could answer them. This paradigm led the product owners to agree that in order to meet the Bureau's obligations and principles, we would focus on reaching users in the orange and blue areas pictured above.

With creative problem solving and faith in the rewards of participatory design, I focused on the goals of UX instead of the deliverables associated with it. I was able to pitch a project vision to two product owners in a way that made them both feel heard, and that everyone on the team could get behind.

Concept

The concept behind the CFPB's HMDA project is to expand access to public data by providing tools that will allow people to find answers about to the mortgage lending industry. Prior to the CFPB taking stewardship of this data, the only way to access it was via the Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council (FFIEC)'s website. Only groups of people in-the-know and with access to expensive software could use and make sense of HMDA data. With our tools, all a person needs is an internet browser.

2.

The problem of usable data was not a new one; a competitor analysis revealed a few efforts to create reference tools using HMDA data. But because the CFPB had inherited the responsibility of caring and grooming for this data, most of our work focused on creating something with a more usable workflow than the one on the FFIEC's website.

We learned that the vast majority users found it difficult or annoying to use a workflow that required them to download full annual data (about 12GB apiece) and use a Windows-only application to narrow down records into raw data or PDFs.

Raw data files used codes instead of plain language to describe the information in each record, and PDFs were unusable in common spreadsheet software. The FFIEC did provide some ready-made reports that did not require using the dataset, but we heard that these were hard to find and people would rather not rely on reports whose subject matter was determined by government agencies.

Users ask one of two things from a HMDA dataset. 1) They want the ability to access it, but usually use only part of it; and 2) they want the ability to summarize millions of records in ways that are easier to think about. These two things must work; providing the wrong facts is the easiest way to lose the trust of both experts and non-experts alike.

Based on this concept and what we heard from users, I sketched a user flow for experts and non-experts in order of basic to complex tasks; a broad to granular data experience. This sketch identified the pages that would comprise the tool, and gave very strong direction to the content for a landing page. Earlier in the project, we expected to build with an API that had the ability to generate charts and graphs, which we believed would be powerful for showing non-expert users the value of our tool. Unfortunately, this did not work out. We worked around this by creating three visualizations to show the kinds of insights that were still possible using other software.

Forming Interactions

The HMDA UI guides people through narrowing down large parts of data into information they care about. In many cases, this will still be millions of records–and it can be overwhelming, even for expert users. To make this a more user-friendly experience, we baked in cues, tucked things out of the way, and held some hands. A special shout-out needs to go to the folks at Harvest for building the Chosen jQuery library, which made most of this possible.

3.

The broad functions of the interface were informed by the existing FFIEC software tool and through the results of design exercises with the product owner. Its final form incorporates psych research about how people wayfind, choose to focus on one thing over another, keep track of information, get overloaded by information, and make sense of abstract terms using plain language. Without putting careful thought into this part of the project, we could make the entire thing flop; HMDA data is hard enough as it is. Beware, I'm going to talk nerdy in this section.

Chunking helps people form clusters of information in meaningful ways. HMDA records include information about a property's location and characteristics, bank or lending institution, loan characteristics, and demographics about the applicant. This information is not grouped this way in the current FFIEC application or within a raw data file. Expert users will find it a chore, but non-expert users would likely find it unusable.

Design exercises confirmed this mental model. Within those broad categories we ordered individual filters based on how useful they would be. We defined useful as types of information most frequently sought by people, and their ability to narrow down filters by a lot.

Raw HMDA data files use numerical codes instead of words to minimize file size. This poses a problem for both expert and non-expert users. We needed to allow experts to move through the filtering process swiftly, using familiar language. For non-experts, we might have to introduce a new type of information for the first time, or explain it in detail. We tested two different versions of the filtering tool, one that just used the names of the variables, and another that guided users to choosing the information they needed by posing a question. We were concerned that the latter would trip up expert users, who might prefer scanning down a list of terms they were familiar with. Using a quick usability test we found that this was not the case. Expert users who wanted to scan through the tool very quickly were focusing on the filters themselves primarily. They were recalling the type of information without even looking at the verbose part of the tool. Everyone's happy, yay!

We fight against cognitive overload by hiding nonessential fields, using plain language in conversational form. We give context to the form by using tooltips, which have content with an explanation of information.

Some HMDA data has hundreds of possible values. We use the magic number seven principle to decide whether to show filters as checkboxes or drop-downs. For those drop-down menus that hold many values, we built in a type to search feature. There are visual cues for filters that can take one value, or many values at a time..

Likewise, with so many records, its hard to keep track of what one's information is or how many records are available. We built natural language features into the UI that summarized the filters into one tidy sentence, or warned them about the size of their downloads. The UI updates in real time, so users get instant feedback as they go along. Together with visual cues, changing your mind about the data you want is no fuss.

This is a long-winded way of saying that the UI was made to be user-friendly, intuitive, and fast.

Iteration

We tested HMDA Explore at various stages of development with our expert and non-expert audiences to figure out where our pain points were and to plan future iterations. Because we also had specific goals for UI elements that were based in research, our usability testing went beyond "general impression" types of tasks. Github played a major role in relaying the feedback we got in these sessions. The wiki feature was used to record findings, and issues were used to request, discuss, and track changes. Github allowed the entire team to join the conversation and follow UX's process.

4.

The HMDA UI incorporates research-based design choices that lessen cognitive overload, encouraging selective attention, and communicate abstract information using familiar syntax and plain language.
